crossref.abstract:
<jats:sec>
                  <jats:title>Background</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>Few data are available on predictors for a favorable outcome in patients with chronic nonspecific low back pain (CNLBP).</jats:p>
               </jats:sec>
               <jats:sec>
                  <jats:title>Purpose</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>The aim of this study was to assess prognostic factors for pain intensity, disability, return to work, quality of life, and global perceived effect in patients with CNLBP at short-term (≤6 months) and long-term (&gt;6 months) follow-up.</jats:p>
               </jats:sec>
               <jats:sec>
                  <jats:title>Data Sources</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>Relevant studies evaluating the prognosis of CNLBP were searched in PubMed, CINAHL, and EMBASE (through March 2010).</jats:p>
               </jats:sec>
               <jats:sec>
                  <jats:title>Study Selection</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>Articles with all types of study designs were included. Inclusion criteria were: participants were patients with CNLBP (≥12 weeks' duration), participants were older than 18 years of age, and the study was related to prognostic factors for recovery. Fourteen studies met the inclusion criteria.</jats:p>
               </jats:sec>
               <jats:sec>
                  <jats:title>Data Extraction</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>Two reviewers extracted the data and details of each study.</jats:p>
               </jats:sec>
               <jats:sec>
                  <jats:title>Data Synthesis</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>A qualitative analysis using “level of evidence” was performed for all included studies. Data were summarized in tables and critically appraised.</jats:p>
               </jats:sec>
               <jats:sec>
                  <jats:title>Limitations</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>The results of the studies reviewed were limited by their methodological weaknesses.</jats:p>
               </jats:sec>
               <jats:sec>
                  <jats:title>Conclusions</jats:title>
                  <jats:p>At short-term follow-up, no association was found for the factors of age and sex with the outcomes of pain intensity and disability. At long-term follow-up, smoking had the same result. At long-term follow-up, pain intensity and fear of movement had no association with disability. At short-term follow-up, conflicting evidence was found for the association between the outcomes pain intensity and disability and the factor of fear of movement. At long-term follow-up, conflicting evidence was found for the factors of age, sex, and physical job demands. At long-term follow-up, conflicting evidence also was found for the association between return to work and age, sex, and activities of daily living. At baseline, there was limited evidence of a positive influence of lower pain intensity and physical job demands on return to work. No high-quality studies were found for the outcomes of quality of life and global perceived effect.</jats:p>
               </jats:sec>
title: Prognostic Factors for Recovery in Chronic Nonspecific Low Back Pain: A Systematic Review

affiliation.name: K. Verkerk, PT, MSc, Rotterdam University of Applied Sciences, Rotterdam, the Netherlands; Spine & Joint Centre, Rotterdam, the Netherlands; Department of General Practice, Erasmus MC, University Medical Center, Rotterdam, the Netherlands. Mailing address: Museumpark 40, 3015 CX Rotterdam, the Netherlands.
P.A.J. Luijsterburg, PhD, Department of General Practice, Erasmus MC, University Medical Center.
H.S. Miedema, MD, Rotterdam University of Applied Sciences.
A. Pool-Goudzwaard, PhD, Department of Neuroscience, Erasmus MC, University Medical Center, Rotterdam.
B.W. Koes, PhD, Department of General Practice, Erasmus MC, University Medical Center.
